repnme.cdata!:
Hungary - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall rating of the operation is
            highly satisfactory. Key lessons learned are: Borrower
            ownership of the program, commitment to its objectives, and
            the drive for results are critical to the successful
            implementation of an ambitious structural reform program.
            The close cooperation between the World bank and the
            Government was instrumental in ensuring design quality and
            effective project. It was determined initially that a core
            set of up-front actions, including the adoption of major new
            legislation, was essential to ensuring effective
            implementation and sustainability of the program's
            objectives. Insistence on this principle extended the period
            preceding the Board presentation; and this period was used
            very effectively to refine the program, gain political
            support at the highest levels in the country, and advance
            bank and enterprise privatization. From the outset, the
            Government determined to sell State-owned enterprises and
            banks to strategic investors who could bring in the
            necessary capital and know-how and provide appropriate
            governance. Putting in place a modern regulatory and
            supervisory framework is crucial to reforming the financial
            sector, but does not itself guarantee effective financial
            sector supervision. While political independence and strong
            regulatory and supervisory powers can be provided relatively
            rapidly by passing appropriate legislation, the development
            of supervisory skills, culture, and confidence is longer-term.

repnme.cdata!:
Hungary - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of the
            Enterprise and Financial Sector Adjustment Loan Project is
            to support Hungary's efforts to implement effective
            reform of its enterprise and financial sectors. The loan
            will provide fast-disbursing funds for balance-of-payments
            assistance for the government's reform program. The
            government will aim to maintain a stable macroeconomic
            framework within which essential structural reforms can be
            implemented, especially those which will accelerate bank and
            enterprise privatization. The reform program's main
            components include: (1) an enterprise privatization program
            targeting substantial reduction of remaining State shares in
            enterprises, particularly in large utilities over the
            1995-97 period; (2) a strong program to curtail and reduce
            enterprise losses, and help free resources for projects of
            much higher returns; (3) comprehensive legal and regulatory
            development in the banking sector designed to preserve
            financial discipline and to ensure that scarce resources are
            effectively allocated to the most dynamic enterprises; and
            (4) radical improvement in bank governance in the context of
            a bank privatization program aimed at privatizing all
            remaining State-owned banks by 1997's end.
